title: Brain Metastases
icd10: C79.32 (Secondary malignant neoplasm of cerebral meninges)
C79.49 (Secondary malignant neoplasm of other parts of nervous system)
scope: ** Management of newly diagnosed or progressive brain metastases in adults. Covers initial stabilization, vasogenic edema management with corticosteroids, seizure management, imaging evaluation, molecular/histopathologic workup, treatment modalities (surgery, stereotactic radiosurgery, whole-brain radiation, systemic therapy with CNS penetration), and disposition. Excludes primary brain tumors (separate template), leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (partially addressed), and spinal metastases (separate template).

Essential/Core Labs.target: WBC, platelets within normal limits; ALC (absolute lymphocyte count) for immunotherapy eligibility

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function for contrast imaging; hepatic function for chemotherapy dosing; electrolytes (SIADH from brain lesions); glucose (steroid hyperglycemia)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; anticipate glucose elevation with dexamethasone

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment; surgical candidacy; hemorrhagic metastases (melanoma, RCC, choriocarcinoma, thyroid)

Essential/Core Labs.target: <180 mg/dL; start insulin if persistently elevated

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Cardiac evaluation if syncope or neurogenic cardiac injury
Treatment planning; β-hCG-secreting tumors (choriocarcinoma, germ cell); radiation contraindication in pregnancy
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; if elevated consider choriocarcinoma or germ cell tumor

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Melanoma staging; tumor burden marker; prognostic
Thyroid primary (thyroid cancer with brain metastases); fatigue/cognitive symptoms differential
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; abnormal may indicate thyroid primary

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Unknown primary: CEA (lung, GI, breast), CA 19-9 (pancreatic, GI), CA 125 (ovarian), CA 15-3 (breast), AFP (hepatocellular, germ cell), β-hCG (choriocarcinoma, germ cell)
Prostate cancer with brain metastases (rare but occurs)
Lymphoma/myeloma differential for CNS mass lesion
Primary CNS lymphoma (PCNSL) differential; immunosuppression assessment; treatment implications
Infection differential (abscess vs. metastasis); inflammatory markers
If pituitary metastasis suspected; before initiating dexamethasone if possible

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Leptomeningeal carcinomatosis evaluation; diagnostic if positive (sensitivity ~50% single LP, ~80% with repeat)
Leptomeningeal disease (elevated protein, low glucose, lymphocytic pleocytosis)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal; elevated protein and low glucose suggest LMD

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Unknown primary; molecular profiling when tissue biopsy not feasible; monitor treatment response
Identify actionable mutations (EGFR, ALK, BRAF, HER2, KRAS, ROS1) when tissue insufficient
If clinical presentation suggests paraneoplastic syndrome mimicking or coexisting with metastatic disease

Lumbar Puncture.item: LP (CPT 62270) with CSF cytology, flow cytometry, protein, glucose, cell count
Lumbar Puncture.timing: If leptomeningeal disease suspected (cranial neuropathies, radiculopathy, headache, altered mentation without adequate parenchymal lesion to explain); MUST ensure no obstructive hydrocephalus or significant mass effect first
Lumbar Puncture.target: Cytology: malignant cells (50% sensitivity single LP; repeat improves to ~80%); elevated opening pressure; elevated protein (>50 mg/dL); low glucose (<40 mg/dL or <60% serum); lymphocytic pleocytosis
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: CONTRAINDICATED if significant mass effect, large posterior fossa lesion, obstructive hydrocephalus, midline shift >5mm (herniation risk); coagulopathy; local infection at LP site

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate in ED for acute presentation; identifies hemorrhage, mass effect, hydrocephalus
Essential/First-line.target: Mass lesion(s), hemorrhage, edema, midline shift, hydrocephalus; hemorrhagic metastases suggest melanoma, RCC, choriocarcinoma, thyroid

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (gadolinium) (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h of presentation; GOLD STANDARD for brain metastases; thin-cut (≤1mm) 3D T1 post-contrast
Essential/First-line.target: Number/size/location of metastases; ring-enhancement pattern; hemorrhagic component; leptomeningeal enhancement; dural-based vs. parenchymal
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; GFR <30 (gadolinium risk); severe claustrophobia

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h if unknown primary; staging for known primary
Essential/First-line.target: Primary tumor identification; staging; additional metastatic disease

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; pre-treatment; QTc for anti-emetics/targeted therapies
Lung primary (most common source of brain metastases); pulmonary metastases; aspiration if obtunded

Extended.timing: Outpatient or during hospitalization; staging; unknown primary identification; ~85% sensitivity for primary site
Extended.target: Primary tumor; additional metastatic disease; lymph node involvement; treatment response assessment

Extended.timing: If hemorrhagic metastasis to evaluate vascularity; pre-surgical planning
Extended.target: Tumor vascularity; relationship to major vessels

Extended.timing: Differentiating tumor from abscess or radiation necrosis; elevated choline:creatine ratio in tumor; lipid/lactate peak in necrosis
Extended.target: Elevated choline, reduced NAA in tumor; elevated lipid/lactate in necrosis

Extended.timing: Differentiating tumor recurrence from radiation necrosis; elevated rCBV in tumor
Extended.target: Elevated rCBV (>1.5-2.0) suggests tumor; low rCBV suggests radiation necrosis

Extended.timing: If spinal symptoms or leptomeningeal disease suspected; staging for drop metastases
Extended.target: Spinal metastases; leptomeningeal enhancement; cord compression

Extended.timing: Breast cancer is 2nd most common source of brain metastases in women
If tissue diagnosis needed and surgical resection not planned; fiducial/frameless navigation sequences
Extended.target: Biopsy trajectory planning; avoidance of eloquent cortex and vasculature

Rare/Advanced.timing: Differentiating recurrent tumor vs. radiation necrosis when MR perfusion/spectroscopy equivocal
Rare/Advanced.target: Increased uptake = tumor; decreased uptake = necrosis

Rare/Advanced.timing: Pre-surgical planning for metastases near eloquent cortex (motor, language areas)
Rare/Advanced.target: Motor/language cortex mapping relative to lesion

Rare/Advanced.timing: Pre-surgical planning; white matter tract relationship to tumor
Biopsy accessible extracranial metastatic site rather than brain (safer, easier tissue acquisition)

dosing.instructions: **Symptomatic edema:** 10 mg IV loading dose, then 4 mg IV/PO q6h; **Moderate symptoms:** 4-8 mg/day; **Severe/impending herniation:** 10 mg IV bolus then 4-8 mg IV q6h (up to 16-24 mg/day); Taper as soon as clinically feasible over 2-4 weeks; GI prophylaxis with PPI (omeprazole 20 mg daily) while on steroids; Monitor glucose q6h initially

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Dexamethasone is preferred corticosteroid (minimal mineralocorticoid effect, long half-life); symptomatic improvement in 24-72h; reduces vasogenic edema via BBB stabilization; no benefit in asymptomatic patients without edema (AVOID routine prophylactic use)

dosing.instructions: **Active seizure:** Lorazepam 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg), may repeat x1 in 5 min; **Then:** Levetiracetam 1000-1500 mg IV load (preferred - no drug interactions with chemotherapy) OR valproic acid 20-30 mg/kg IV load (avoid with hepatic metastases); Phenytoin/fosphenytoin only if above unavailable (interacts with many chemotherapies and targeted agents)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Levetiracetam preferred: no hepatic enzyme induction (does NOT reduce efficacy of steroids, chemotherapy, or targeted agents), renal elimination, broad spectrum; AAN guidelines do NOT recommend prophylactic AEDs in brain tumor patients without seizures

dosing.instructions: Do NOT start AEDs prophylactically in patients with brain metastases who have NOT had seizures; Applicable even peri-operatively (surgical prophylaxis may be used 7 days only per institutional protocol)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: AAN Practice Parameter (Glantz et al., 2000; reaffirmed): No evidence supporting prophylactic AED use in brain tumor patients; side effects outweigh benefits; ASCO guideline concordant

dosing.instructions: **GCS ≤8:** Intubation; elevate HOB 30°; **Acute herniation:** Mannitol 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus OR hypertonic saline (23.4% NaCl 30 mL via central line over 15 min or 3% NaCl 250 mL over 30 min); maintain PaCO2 30-35 mmHg (brief hyperventilation only as bridge to definitive treatment); Emergent neurosurgery consult for decompression

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: ICP management as bridge to definitive treatment (surgery/radiation); prolonged hyperventilation causes cerebral ischemia; osmotherapy reduces cerebral edema

dosing.instructions: SCDs (sequential compression devices) immediately on admission; Pharmacologic prophylaxis: enoxaparin 40 mg SQ daily or heparin 5000 units SQ q8h - START within 24-48h unless hemorrhagic metastasis or planned surgery within 24h; Post-craniotomy: restart pharmacologic DVT ppx within 24-48h per neurosurgery guidance

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Brain tumor patients have 20-30% VTE risk; mechanical prophylaxis alone insufficient; pharmacologic prophylaxis does NOT significantly increase intracranial hemorrhage risk (Perry et al., 2009; AVERT trial)

dosing.instructions: PPI (omeprazole 20 mg daily or pantoprazole 40 mg daily) while on dexamethasone; continue throughout steroid course

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Combined corticosteroid + critical illness increases GI bleed risk

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** Single (or limited ≤3) accessible metastasis; need for tissue diagnosis; symptomatic mass effect not responding to steroids; large lesion (>3-4 cm) not suitable for SRS alone; good performance status (KPS ≥70); controlled systemic disease; life expectancy >3 months; **Post-op:** MRI within 24-48h to assess residual; SRS to cavity within 2-4 weeks to reduce local recurrence (50-60% → 15-20%)

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Patchell et al. (1990): Surgery + WBRT > WBRT alone for single brain metastasis (median survival 40 vs. 15 weeks); Cavity SRS post-resection: Mahajan et al. (2017): local control improved with cavity SRS vs. observation

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** 1-4 metastases (most centers), up to 10-15 in select cases (JLGK0901); size ≤3-4 cm; **Dose:** Single fraction 15-24 Gy (dose based on size: ≤2cm: 20-24 Gy, 2.1-3cm: 18 Gy, 3.1-4cm: 15 Gy) OR fractionated SRS (3-5 fractions for larger lesions or eloquent location); **Timing:** Within 2-4 weeks of diagnosis; Serial MRI q2-3 months post-SRS

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Yamamoto et al. (JLGK0901): SRS alone for 2-10 metastases non-inferior to 2-4 for survival; SRS vs. WBRT: better cognitive preservation (NCCTG N0574, Brown et al., 2016); SRS + HA-WBRT vs SRS alone per NRG-CC003

dosing.instructions: **Indications:** >10-15 metastases; leptomeningeal disease; poor surgical/SRS candidates; miliary/diffuse pattern; **Standard:** 30 Gy in 10 fractions (or 20 Gy in 5 fractions for poor prognosis); **Hippocampal avoidance (HA-WBRT):** Preferred when technically feasible (no metastases within 5mm of hippocampus): 30 Gy in 10 fractions with hippocampal sparing + memantine 20 mg daily starting with WBRT x 6 months

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: HA-WBRT + memantine (NRG-CC001, Brown et al., 2020): significantly less cognitive deterioration vs. standard WBRT + memantine at 4 and 6 months; Memantine alone (RTOG 0614): trend toward better cognitive function

dosing.instructions: **NSCLC with EGFR mutation:** Osimertinib 80 mg daily (CNS response rate 91%); **NSCLC with ALK rearrangement:** Lorlatinib 100 mg daily (intracranial response 82%) or alectinib 600 mg BID (CNS response 81%); **NSCLC with ROS1:** Lorlatinib; **Melanoma with BRAF V600:** Dabrafenib + trametinib (intracranial response 58%) or encorafenib + binimetinib; **Melanoma (any):** Ipilimumab + nivolumab (intracranial response 46-57% in asymptomatic); **HER2+ breast:** Tucatinib + trastuzumab + capecitabine (HER2CLIMB: intracranial response 47%); **Breast (HR+):** Abemaciclib (some CNS activity); **RCC:** Nivolumab + ipilimumab or cabozantinib

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: CNS-penetrant systemic therapy increasingly used as upfront or adjunct to SRS; may defer radiation in asymptomatic patients with actionable mutations and small metastases; Always coordinate with medical oncology

dosing.instructions: Begin taper once definitive treatment initiated and symptoms improving; **Taper schedule:** Reduce by 2 mg every 3-5 days (from 16 mg/day: 16→12→8→6→4→2→1→off); Slower taper if symptoms recur; Monitor for adrenal insufficiency if >3 weeks of steroid use

Definitive/Targeted Treatment.monitoring: Prolonged steroids cause significant morbidity: hyperglycemia, myopathy (steroid myopathy can be debilitating), immunosuppression, osteoporosis, PJP risk, insomnia, psychiatric effects, GI bleeding

dosing.instructions: 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID (start 500 mg BID, titrate to seizure control); Renal dosing if GFR <50; No drug interactions with chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or steroids

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Preferred AED in brain tumor patients due to no CYP enzyme induction; does not reduce efficacy of dexamethasone, temozolomide, or targeted agents

dosing.instructions: If dexamethasone >20 mg/week AND concomitant temozolomide or immunosuppression: TMP-SMX 1 DS tablet 3x/week (Mon/Wed/Fri) OR atovaquone 1500 mg daily if sulfa allergic

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Risk of Pneumocystis with prolonged corticosteroids + additional immunosuppression

dosing.instructions: Fingerstick glucose q6h while on dexamethasone; Sliding scale insulin initially; Basal-bolus insulin if persistently >180 mg/dL; Anticipate glucose elevation typically 4-8 hours after steroid dose; May need 2-3x baseline insulin requirements

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Dexamethasone causes significant hyperglycemia in 50-60% of patients; uncontrolled hyperglycemia worsens outcomes

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU daily while on prolonged steroids (>2 weeks)
Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV/PO q8h PRN; Dexamethasone itself is anti-emetic; Avoid metoclopramide in brain metastases patients (extrapyramidal effects)

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: Nausea common with elevated ICP and with radiation therapy

dosing.instructions: 5 mg daily x1 week → 5 mg BID x1 week → 10 mg AM + 5 mg PM x1 week → 10 mg BID; Continue for 6 months total; Start day 1 of WBRT

Adjunctive Treatment.monitoring: RTOG 0614 and NRG-CC001: cognitive protection during WBRT; NMDA receptor antagonist reduces excitotoxic neuronal injury from radiation

differential.features: Usually single; irregular enhancement; often involves corpus callosum (butterfly GBM); no known systemic cancer; infiltrative margins; surrounding FLAIR/T2 more extensive; restricted diffusion at tumor margins
differential.tests: MRI pattern; MR spectroscopy (elevated choline:creatine, reduced NAA); biopsy (IDH, MGMT, 1p19q); no systemic disease on staging CT/PET

differential.features: Periventricular location; homogeneously enhancing; restricted diffusion; may be multifocal; immunocompromised patients; responds dramatically to corticosteroids (may "disappear" = ghost tumor); typically does NOT ring-enhance unless HIV
differential.tests: MRI with diffusion restriction; AVOID steroids before biopsy if possible (may render biopsy non-diagnostic); CSF flow cytometry; vitreous biopsy if ocular involvement; HIV testing; slit lamp exam

differential.features: Ring-enhancing lesion with restricted diffusion on DWI (bright on DWI, dark on ADC in the cavity — metastases typically do NOT show central restricted diffusion); fever, elevated WBC; recent sinusitis/otitis/dental procedure/endocarditis; thin smooth enhancing rim; satellite lesions
differential.tests: DWI: central restricted diffusion is KEY distinguishing feature; MR spectroscopy: amino acid peaks (succinate, acetate, lactate); blood cultures; echocardiogram; source identification

differential.features: HIV/AIDS (CD4 <100); multiple ring-enhancing lesions; basal ganglia predilection; eccentric target sign; edema/mass effect
differential.tests: Toxoplasma IgG (serum); CD4 count; empiric treatment trial (response in 10-14 days supports diagnosis); if no response → biopsy; Thallium SPECT (increased uptake = lymphoma, not toxoplasmosis)

differential.features: Incomplete ring enhancement (open ring sign); younger patients; clinical dissemination in time/space; less mass effect relative to lesion size; leading edge enhancement
differential.tests: MRI: open ring enhancement, T2/FLAIR lesions in MS-typical locations; CSF: oligoclonal bands; MOG/AQP4 antibodies; clinical response to steroids

differential.features: History of prior brain radiation (typically 6-24 months post-treatment but can occur later); enhancing lesion at site of prior radiation; difficult to distinguish from recurrent tumor on conventional MRI
differential.tests: MR perfusion: LOW rCBV (vs. tumor with HIGH rCBV); MR spectroscopy: elevated lipid/lactate, low choline; PET: low FDG uptake (vs. tumor with high uptake); biopsy if equivocal

differential.features: Travel/residence in endemic area (Latin America, sub-Saharan Africa, Southeast Asia); cystic lesions with scolex (dot within cyst); often calcified in chronic phase; seizure is common presentation
differential.tests: MRI: cystic lesion with scolex; CT: calcified granulomas; serology (cysticercosis antibodies); stool ova/parasites

differential.features: Vascular territory distribution; ring enhancement at 1-4 weeks post-stroke (luxury perfusion); clinical history of acute onset; DWI abnormalities conforming to vascular territory
differential.tests: Timing of enhancement (subacute strokes enhance transiently); vascular territory distribution; DWI/ADC map evolution; clinical history of acute onset

differential.features: Hemorrhage into metastasis; acute hydrocephalus; herniation
differential.tests: STAT CT head; neurosurgery STAT; consider intubation

differential.features: Peri-tumoral irritation; hemorrhage; edema worsening; leptomeningeal spread
differential.tests: CT head (rule out hemorrhage); start AED (levetiracetam); re-image with MRI

differential.features: Hemorrhagic metastasis (especially melanoma, RCC); pituitary apoplexy from pituitary metastasis
differential.tests: STAT CT head; CT angiography if SAH pattern

differential.features: Brain abscess (metastasis can be misdiagnosed as abscess and vice versa); infection in immunocompromised patient; central fever from brain lesion
differential.tests: Blood cultures; CT head; LP if safe; broad-spectrum antibiotics if infection suspected

differential.features: Pituitary metastasis with apoplexy; optic nerve/chiasm compression
Spinal cord compression from spinal metastases; leptomeningeal disease affecting cauda equina
differential.tests: STAT MRI whole spine; dexamethasone 10 mg IV; neurosurgery/radiation oncology STAT

differential.features: Prolonged dexamethasone; immunosuppression; hyperglycemia; myopathy; osteoporosis
differential.tests: Taper steroids; manage complications; alternative edema management (bevacizumab for radiation necrosis)

evidence.evidenceLevel: Congress of Neurological Surgeons (CNS) / AANS Systematic Review
NCCN Central Nervous System Cancers
[AAN Practice Parameter (Glantz et al.)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/41456935/)
[NRG-CC001 (Brown et al.)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32058845/)
[JLGK0901 (Yamamoto et al.)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24621620/)
[NCCTG N0574 (Brown et al.)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27458945/)
Surgery + WBRT vs. WBRT alone for single brain metastasis: median survival 40 vs. 15 weeks; lower recurrence at original site (20% vs. 52%)
evidence.source: Established surgery as standard for single brain metastasis

evidence.evidenceLevel: Post-operative WBRT reduced brain recurrence (18% vs. 70%) but no survival benefit; improved neurologic death
evidence.source: Supported adjuvant radiation after surgery; now often SRS to cavity instead of WBRT

evidence.evidenceLevel: SRS to surgical cavity vs. observation: 12-month local recurrence 28% vs. 59% (HR 0.46)
evidence.source: Established post-operative cavity SRS as standard of care

evidence.evidenceLevel: SRS alone vs. SRS + WBRT: cognitive deterioration at 3 months 64% vs. 92%; no OS difference
evidence.source: Shifted practice toward SRS alone with surveillance MRI rather than WBRT

evidence.evidenceLevel: SRS for 5-10 vs. 2-4 brain metastases: similar overall survival (10.8 vs. 10.8 months)
evidence.source: Expanded SRS indications to higher numbers of metastases

evidence.evidenceLevel: HA-WBRT + memantine vs. WBRT + memantine: less cognitive deterioration at 4 months (59% vs. 68%) and 6 months; less decline in executive function and memory
evidence.source: HA-WBRT + memantine = new standard when WBRT indicated

evidence.evidenceLevel: Ipilimumab + nivolumab in melanoma brain metastases: intracranial response 57% in asymptomatic patients
evidence.source: Established immunotherapy as upfront option for melanoma brain metastases

evidence.evidenceLevel: Osimertinib CNS response rate 91% in EGFR-mutant NSCLC with brain metastases vs. 68% standard EGFR TKI
evidence.source: Established osimertinib as preferred first-line for EGFR+ NSCLC with brain metastases

evidence.evidenceLevel: Tucatinib + trastuzumab + capecitabine: intracranial response 47%; CNS-PFS 9.9 vs. 4.2 months; OS benefit in brain metastases subgroup
evidence.source: Established tucatinib combination as standard for HER2+ breast cancer brain metastases

evidence.evidenceLevel: Dalteparin vs. placebo in malignant glioma: no increase in intracranial hemorrhage with anticoagulation; VTE reduction
evidence.source: Supported pharmacologic DVT prophylaxis in brain tumor patients

evidence.evidenceLevel: Bevacizumab for radiation necrosis: significant radiographic and clinical improvement in ~65% of patients
evidence.source: Established bevacizumab as treatment option for symptomatic radiation necrosis refractory to steroids

monitoring.item: Neurologic checks (GCS, pupil reactivity, motor exam, speech)
monitoring.frequency: q1-2h in ICU; q2-4h on floor
monitoring.action: Stat CT head if decline; neurosurgery alert; consider increasing dexamethasone or osmotherapy
Sliding scale → basal-bolus insulin; typically requires 2-3x baseline insulin on dexamethasone

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor
monitoring.action: Antihypertensives PRN; avoid excessive hypotension (SBP >100 to maintain cerebral perfusion)
Hyponatremia common (SIADH, cerebral salt wasting); free water restriction if SIADH
If <130: fluid restrict; if <125 or symptomatic: 3% NaCl; if rapidly dropping: urgent sodium correction

monitoring.frequency: Continuous observation; consider cEEG if altered mental status
monitoring.action: AED initiation/adjustment; neurology consultation; continuous EEG monitoring
Acetaminophen 650-1000 mg q6h; dexamethasone (reduces headache from edema); opioids PRN for moderate-severe

monitoring.frequency: q2-3 months for first year post-treatment, then q3-4 months year 2, then q6 months
monitoring.target: Stable/decreasing lesion size; no new metastases
monitoring.action: New/progressive lesions: repeat multidisciplinary discussion; salvage SRS, surgery, systemic therapy change

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit (q2-4 weeks during treatment, q1-3 months maintenance)
monitoring.action: New deficits: urgent MRI; consider tumor progression vs. radiation necrosis vs. new metastasis
KPS <50 / ECOG ≥3: reassess goals of care; transition to supportive/palliative care
Steroid-dependent edema: consider bevacizumab, re-irradiation, or resection to enable taper
Insulin titration; endocrine consultation if difficult to control

monitoring.frequency: Per chemotherapy cycle protocol; typically q2-3 weeks

monitoring.action: Dose adjustment; drug-specific monitoring per protocol

monitoring.frequency: q3-6 months; MoCA or formal neuropsychological testing
monitoring.action: Cognitive rehabilitation; medication review; assess for depression; differentiate radiation injury vs. progression
SSRI (avoid CYP interactions); psychology referral; supportive care

disposition.criteria: GCS ≤12; signs of herniation (pupil asymmetry, posturing, Cushing triad); acute hemorrhage into metastasis with neurologic decline; post-craniotomy (first 24h); status epilepticus; respiratory compromise requiring intubation; hemodynamic instability

New diagnosis requiring workup and treatment planning; symptomatic edema requiring IV dexamethasone; post-seizure requiring monitoring and AED optimization; post-craniotomy (step-down from ICU); functional decline requiring inpatient rehabilitation planning
Known brain metastases with mild symptom change; MRI revealing progression but patient clinically stable; steroid dose adjustment with monitoring
Stable or improving neurologic exam for ≥24h on current steroid dose; no new deficits
Seizure-free ≥24h on oral AED; no breakthrough seizures; AED levels therapeutic if applicable
Oral dexamethasone regimen established with clear taper schedule; glucose management plan in place
Headache adequately controlled on oral medications
Multidisciplinary plan documented (surgery, radiation, systemic therapy); appointments scheduled within 1-2 weeks
Safe ambulation (with or without assistive device); safe swallowing; able to perform basic ADLs or adequate caregiver support
Transition to pharmacologic prophylaxis or therapeutic anticoagulation plan if VTE occurred

Neurosurgery (1-2 weeks if post-op), radiation oncology (1-2 weeks for SRS/WBRT planning), medical oncology (1-2 weeks), PCP (1 week for steroid monitoring); MRI brain scheduled at appropriate interval
Understanding of diagnosis, treatment plan, steroid side effects, seizure precautions, when to return to ED (acute headache, new weakness, seizure, vision changes, fever)
Taper schedule clearly documented (e.g., 4 mg q6h x 3 days → 4 mg q8h x 3 days → 4 mg q12h x 3 days → 4 mg daily x 3 days → 2 mg daily x 3 days → stop)
Omeprazole 20 mg daily or pantoprazole 40 mg daily while on steroids
Levetiracetam dose and frequency; DO NOT start if no seizure history
Sliding scale or basal-bolus regimen for steroid-induced hyperglycemia; glucometer and supplies
If steroids >2 weeks anticipated
Enoxaparin transition plan if VTE occurred
Acetaminophen; limited opioid prescription if needed
If on high-dose steroids + chemotherapy (PJP prophylaxis)
